texts.shortText: Large, conspicuous and well-known anemone. Body fairly wide and squat, base with undulating edges. Column smooth and uniform yellow, orange or red. Tentacles paler orange to yellow, fairly long, numbering up to 230, usually with purple tips and generally held extended perpendicular to column. Unusual in that it has a weak sphincter and is thus unable to fully close up when disturbed. Three to five rows of globular vesicles immediately beneath the tentacles are used for combat.
Column reaches a diameter of at least 75 mm, so tentacles can have a span of over 100 mm.

Global: Widespread, with records from Brazil, Norway and Azores, as well as common in Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about St Lucia in KwaZulu-Natal.

A large and conspicuous species, particularly common in low intertidal pools and on shallow reefs, but recorded down to at least 46 m depth. Unusual in that the sphincter is weak and so the tentacles cannot be completely withdrawn, so is permanently ‘open’. Well known for its territorial behaviour, individuals inflating their vesicles and using them to attack and sometimes kill unrelated individuals. Where several similarly-coloured individuals occur in close proximity these are thus almost certainly genetically-identical and derived from fission of a founding individual.

The venom of the stinging cells is particularly potent and captive animals in the marine aquarium have been observed to capture juvenile catsharks on several occasions. The catsharks, which settles on an expanded anemone, were instantly paralysed and offered no resistance as they were slowly dragged into the mouth by the tentacles and swallowed. If one touches these anemones with a finger the stinging cells fire and the tentacles stick into the skin, but the venom is unable to penetrate the dead epidermis, so the sting is not painful (in case of allergic reaction, it is unrecommended trying this though!).

Feeds on a variety of larger invertebrates and also the only regional species to routinely take fish. An analysis of gut contents on the Cape Peninsula revealed the diet to consists of 43% gastropods, 18% bivalves, 18% isopods and 12% echinoderms; but as echinoderms were larger they accounted for 51% of the diet by mass.

Anemones can reproduce sexually, but releasing sperm and eggs into the water, but can also divide by fission, so where similarly-coloured individuals are found in close proximity the group is probably derived by division of a single founding individual.

Easily confused with the closely-related Pseudactinia varia which is also found in much the same habitat. That species, however, smaller, and is usually paler pink in colour with fewer, lighter-coloured tentacles, which also lack purple tips. There are also only 1–2 rows of vesicles beneath the tentacles.
